column2:
A is used when the following word could be any of a certain type.

Synonyms: one, any and each
If you abandon something, you go away from it with no plan to return.
If someone is able to do something, he can do it.
When you abolish something, you end it by making it invalid or illegal. You usually use the word "abolish" in regard to laws or actions.
You use about to say what subject something is related to.
If A is above B, A is higher than or before B, but not touching B.
If something is absent, it means to be not in a place or missing.

An absolute is something that will always exist.

Synonym: none

If something is absorbed, it is sucked or soaked up .

Synonyms: draw, imbibe and suck

If something is absorbent, it can soak up liquid.

Synonym: absorptive
If something is abstract, you cannot touch it, and it is difficult to imagine or think about.
Something absurd is ridiculous and stupid.
Abuse is touching or acting towards someone in a way that will likely hurt them.
If someone is abusive, he is violent and abuses  others.
If you accomplish something, you succeed in doing it.
If you accumulate something, you bring it together.
If you achieve success or a goal, you have completed what you planned to do or have a good result.
Related to hearing or sounds.

To the other side.

Synonym: over

&  If you act in some way, you do something that makes people think you are that way.

Synonyms: do, work and behave
The past tense and past participle of act.
Something is active if it is turned on or started.
When a person or animal has activity, it is active or lively.
A female actor.

If an angle is acute, it is less than 90 degrees in size.

Antonym: obtuse
If you adapt to changes, conditions, needs, etc., you change to fit them.

An addict is someone who is addicted to something, most often to a harmful drug.

Synonyms: junkie and slave
If something is addictive, it is hard to stop doing it.
An address is the location where a building is or where a person lives.
The third-person singular form of add.
If you adjust something, you change it a little so that it fits or works better.

administrative (comparative more administrative, superlative most administrative)
Of or relating to administering or administration.
If you admire something, you like it very much.
The third-person singular form of admire.
If you admit someone, you allow them to enter an area or a building.
The third-person singular form of admit.
If you adopt something, you choose and begin to use it instead of what you used in the past.
The past participle of adopt.
If you adore someone, you love them very much.
An adult is a person who is of the legal age of majority.

If you advertise something, you make it known publicly, usually to sell it.

Synonyms: push, promote, present, market, broadcast and announce
An advisor is a person who gives advice.
If something is affordable, it can be afforded.
If you are afraid of something, you feel fear, or worry because you think something bad will happen.
Behind something in place or position.
The time after 12:00  and before the evening meal.
Once more.
In opposition, or not agreeing, to.

Something's age is how long it has existed or been alive; how old something is.

Synonym: time
Making attacks or assaults that are not just.
At an earlier time.
Agony is extremely bad suffering with strong pain
When two people agree about something, they have the same ideas. They both think the same things are true.
If something is agreeable, it is nice and good.
An agreement is where everybody has the same feelings about something; when everyone has the same ideas; saying "yes".
Aid is the help that is given to people, usually by a government or institution.
The past tense and past participle of aid.
An aim is something you want to do or have done.
Air is a mixture of gases. It has no color or odor

algae
plural form of alga
An alien is a person, animal, plant or thing that is not part of the group you look at.
If you align some things, you make them point the same direction.
If someone or something is alive, it is living or it continues to exist. If you are alive you have life.
All of something is 100% of it, or the entire amount.
If you allow something, you let it happen; you say it's OK.
An almond is the nut which comes from the almond tree.
Very nearly; about 98% of something; not the same, but near to being the same.
If someone is alone, they are not with other people.
before a certain time
When one thing happens and a second thing happens in a same or similar time or way, then the second thing also happens.
If you alter something, you change it, usually in a small way.
You use although to show an idea that is surprising or different from another idea.
If something always happens, it happens at all times or every time.
A form of the verb be used about the person speaking
If a person is amiable, they are friendly, pleasant and/or agreeable
In or into. We say "between" 2 other things, but among 3 or more other things.

amp (plural amps)
(colloquial) ampere, the unit of electrical current.
(colloquial) amplifier.[1]
(colloquial) ampoule.
(colloquial) amputee.

amputate (third-person singular simple present amputates, present participle amputating, simple past and past participle amputated)
To surgically remove a part of the body, especially a limb
To amuse is to cause laughter and enjoyment; to be funny.
An  is used when the following word could be any of a certain type.

You use and to talk about two things at once.

Synonyms: in addition to and as well as
When two straight lines come together, they make an angle.
The plural form of animal; more than one animal.

If something annoys people, it makes them angry or bothered. This often happens after someone does an action many times.

Synonyms: rag, bother, rile, irritate, nettle, chafe, nark, vex, gravel and devil


Antonym: delight

anoint (third-person singular simple present anoints, present participle anointing, simple past and past participle anointed)
(transitive) To smear or rub over with oil or an unctuous substance; also, to spread over, as oil.And fragrant oils the stiffened limbs anoint. —Dryden.He anointed the eyes of the blind man with the clay. —John ix. 6.
And fragrant oils the stiffened limbs anoint. —Dryden.
He anointed the eyes of the blind man with the clay. —John ix. 6.
(transitive) To apply oil to or to pour oil upon, etc., as a sacred rite, especially for consecration.Then shalt thou take the anointing oil, and pour it upon his [Aaron's] head and anoint him. —Exod. xxix. 7.Anoint Hazael to be king over Syria. —1 Kings xix. 15.
Then shalt thou take the anointing oil, and pour it upon his [Aaron's] head and anoint him. —Exod. xxix. 7.
Anoint Hazael to be king over Syria. —1 Kings xix. 15.
(transitive, figuratively) To choose or nominate somebody for a leading or otherwise important position, especially formally or officially, or as an intended successor.
(transitive, historical) To mark somebody as an official ruler, especially a king or queen, as a part of a religious ceremony.
Another of something means that there is one more of it.
An ant is an insect that walks and goes in groups.

antenna (plural antennae or antennas)
A feeler organ on the head of an insect, crab, or other animal.
An apparatus to receive or transmit radio waves and convert respectively to or from an electrical signal.
The faculty of intuitive astuteness.2006 Kelly Pyrek, Forensic Nursing, page 5, ISBN 084933540X.Most nurses believe they are born with an antenna of sorts, which is able to guide them through clinical practice and help them determine what is right and what is not...2010 Mary Lou Decostérd, Right Brain/Left Brain President: Barack Obama's Uncommon Leadership Ability, page 106, ISBN 0313380724.Obama is astute. He approaches things with the help of a sensitive antenna.
2006 Kelly Pyrek, Forensic Nursing, page 5, ISBN 084933540X.Most nurses believe they are born with an antenna of sorts, which is able to guide them through clinical practice and help them determine what is right and what is not...
2010 Mary Lou Decostérd, Right Brain/Left Brain President: Barack Obama's Uncommon Leadership Ability, page 106, ISBN 0313380724.Obama is astute. He approaches things with the help of a sensitive antenna.

antics
plural of antic
An antique is something that is old for its type.
some or even the smallest amount or number
Any person. You use this when there is no limit to who might be meant. You might be able to change "anyone" to any person's name.
Any one of all things. You use this when there is no limit to what might be meant. You might be able to change "anything" to any other word.
Any place.
An apartment is a place with several rooms in a building where other people also live.
A primate without a tail including chimpanzees, gorillas, orangutans and humans.
An apology is words or actions that show you are sorry.
A complex machine or instrument.
An appeal is a strong or official request.
If something appears a certain way, it looks or seems that way.
The third-person singular form of appear.
An appendix is a part at the back of a book that has extra information.
An apple is a sweet, red, yellow or green fruit.
If a rule, a principle, a law, etc. applies, it has some effect on the situation.
If you appoint someone to a job or position, you give the job to them.
If you approach something, you move closer to it.
The present participle of approach.

If a person in power approves something such as a plan, a sale, a rule, etc., they say it is OK and it may go ahead.

Synonyms: permission, allow and permit


Antonyms: reject and disapprove

aquarium (plural aquaria or aquariums)
A tank, often made of glass, for keeping live fish or other aquatic animals.
A public place where live fish and other aquatic animals are exhibited.
Archery is a sport where people shoot bows and arrows.
Are is the present tense, second person form of the verb be.
If you argue with someone, you debate, disagree or talk about your differing ideas.
If you are arrested you are caught by the police.
If you arrive somewhere, you come to that place, usually the place that you planned to go to.
An artist is someone who makes art.
If something is artistic, it is an example of good art.
A word that is used to compare two things that are equal.
If you put something aside, you put it to the side, often because you want to use it later.
To ask is to look for an answer to a question by saying it.
The third-person singular form of ask.

asphalt (plural asphalts)
A sticky, black and highly viscous liquid or semi-solid, composed almost entirely of bitumen, that is present in most crude petroleums and in some natural deposits.
asphalt concrete, a hard ground covering used for roads and walkways.
If you assemble many people or things, you bring them together.
When you assign a job to someone, you tell them to do it.
An assistant is a person who helps  another person.

astound (third-person singular simple present astounds, present participle astounding, simple past and past participle astounded)
To astonish, bewilder or dazzle.
Used to describe where something is, or when saying something's position
The past tense of eat.

athletic (comparative more athletic, superlative most athletic)
(not comparable) Having to do with athletes.Are you a member of the American Athletic Association?
Physically active.Since you're such an athletic person, you may wish to consider joining.
Having a muscular, well developed body, being in shape.You have such an athletic build—you must work out regularly.
An attribute of a motion or play which requires fine physical ability.The center fielder made an athletic play to snatch the ball from over the fence.
;  An atmosphere is a layer of gasses that surrounds a planet.
To begin fighting with.
An attempt is a try at something, usually something difficult

attentive (comparative more attentive, superlative most attentive)
Paying attention; noticing, watching, listening, or attending closely.She is an attentive listener, but does not like to talk much.
Courteous; mindful.a husband attentive to his wife's needs

attorney (plural attorneys)
(US) A lawyer; one who advises or represents others in legal matters as a profession.
(UK 19th century and earlier) One such who practised in the courts of the common law (cf solicitor, proctor).
(Britain, 20th century and later, rare, usually pejorative) A solicitor.
(obsolete outside set phrases) An agent or representative authorized to act on someone else's behalf.
(Philippines) A title given to lawyers and notaries public, or those holders by profession who also do other jobs. Usually capitalized or abbreviated as Atty.

attractively (comparative more attractively, superlative most attractively)
In an attractive manner; with the power of attracting or drawing to.
Auburn is a color often used to describe hair color.
Of the same origin as claimed; genuine.
An author is the creator of a work; a writer.
To have authority means to have the power to make a decision.
To authorize someone is to give them power or permission.

autograph (plural autographs)
A person’s own handwriting, especially the signature of a famous or admired person.
A manuscript in the author’s handwriting.

autograph (plural autographs)
A person’s own handwriting, especially the signature of a famous or admired person.
A manuscript in the author’s handwriting.

If something is automatic, it works by itself.

Antonym: manual

autopsy (plural autopsies)
A dissection performed on a cadaver to find possible cause(s) of death.
An after-the-fact examination, especially of the causes of a failure.
(rare) An eyewitness observation, the presentation of an event as witnessed.
The season when the weather is getting colder, after summer and before winter.
If something is available, it exists and you can use it.

avid (comparative more avid, superlative most avid)
enthusiastic; passionate; longing eagerly; eager; greedyI'm an avid reader.1996, Janette Turner Hospital, Oyster, Virago Press, paperback edition, page 3We waited for something to happen, for anything to happen, we were avid for some event to unfold itself out of the burning nothing to save us.
1996, Janette Turner Hospital, Oyster, Virago Press, paperback edition, page 3We waited for something to happen, for anything to happen, we were avid for some event to unfold itself out of the burning nothing to save us.

awaits
plural of await
Alert, not asleep.
An award is something that you give to someone who has done something very well.
The plural form of award; more than one award.
When something moves away from something else, the distance between them gets bigger. They are no longer near or close.

awning (plural awnings)
A rooflike cover, usually of canvas, extended over or before any place as a shelter from the sun, rain, or wind.
(nautical) That part of the poop deck which is continued forward beyond the bulkhead of the cabin.
The past tense of awake.
Ax is another way of spelling axe.
A baby or infant, often used in poetry.

A very young child, less than two years old, who has not yet learned how to speak.

Synonyms: child and infant
Toward the rear.
The background is what can be seen or heard behind other things that are closer or louder.
If something is bad, it is not good.
Badminton is a sport where players hit a shuttlecock over a high net using long handled racquets.
Bags are containers made of soft material like paper, plastic or leather.
When clothes are baggy, they are very loose.
The plural form of bag; more than one bag.
A bail is an amount of money paid for the release of someone who has been arrested with the promise that he/she will appear in court for a trial.
Bait is food placed on a hook to catch fish or other animals
If you bake something, you cook it with dry heat all around it, usually in an oven.
A bakery is a place where bread and similar kinds of food are baked and sold.
The third-person singular form of bake.
Someone who is bald has no hair on his or her head.

baldness (countable and uncountable, plural baldnesses)
The state of being bald.My baldness was the result of radiotherapy.the baldness of an assertion
A bale is a large bundle, or package, tied with wire, rope, or string.
A ball is a round thing. People often use them to play games.

balmy (comparative balmier, superlative balmiest)
Producing balm.
Soothing or fragrant.
Mild and pleasant.
(informal) Foolish; slightly crazy or mad; eccentric.Roald Dahl, Parson's Pleasure'I reckon he's balmy,' Claud said, and Bert grinned darkly, rolling his misty eye slowly round in its socket.
Roald Dahl, Parson's Pleasure'I reckon he's balmy,' Claud said, and Bert grinned darkly, rolling his misty eye slowly round in its socket.
If you ban someone, you disallow or block someone from doing something.
A long fruit with smooth yellow skin.
A band is a group of people working together.
A bandit is person, usually in a group, who uses guns to rob people.
A bang is a short loud noise like the sound of a door closing or a gun being shot.
A building where you can keep and borrow money.
If you are bankrupt you have declared bankruptcy .
A barber is a person whose job is cutting hair and shaving beards.
The outside part of a tree; the skin of the tree.
A barn is a building found on a farm where animals live .
A barrel is a tall and round container.
The plural form of barrel; more than one barrel.

barricade (plural barricades)
A barrier constructed across a road, especially as a military defence
An obstacle, barrier, or bulwark.DerhamSuch a barricade as would greatly annoy, or absolutely stop, the currents of the atmosphere.
DerhamSuch a barricade as would greatly annoy, or absolutely stop, the currents of the atmosphere.
(figuratively, in the plural) A place of confrontation.

The lower part of anything; the solid part that touches the floor or touches the earth and keeps the other parts of the thing up.

Synonym: foundation
A sport where you try to hit a ball so that you can run to four bases, causing a run. The team with the most runs after nine or more innings wins.
A basement is part of a house or building that is under the ground.
When something is basic, it is simple.
A basket is something like a bucket but with many holes like a net, made of soft sticks or grass or other long, thin material. People put things in the basket.
A ball game with two teams of five players. A goal is scored when a player throws the ball into a net  at each end of the court.
The bass is a sound that is generally lower in tone.
A bat is a small, furry animal  that has wings and can fly.
A batch of things or people is a group that are dealt with at one time.
A long, high basin that you put water in and go in to wash your body.

When you bathe, you clean yourself with water.

Synonym: bath

bathrobe (plural bathrobes)
A robe usually made of terrycloth intended to be worn when one is still damp from bathing or when there is no immediate need to dress fully.
A bathroom is a room that has a bathtub or a shower.
A batter is somebody who is supposed to hit a ball with a bat.

A battle is when different groups or teams fight each other.

Synonyms: action, conflict, contest and fight

bawl (third-person singular simple present bawls, present participle bawling, simple past and past participle bawled)
(transitive) To shout or utter in a loud and intense manner.
(intransitive) To wail; to give out a blaring cry.
A bay is water with land around most of it.
This verb tells us that a thing is present, or in a place.
A large area of sand , next to an area of water.
Beans are the seeds of one family of plants that people often cook and eat.
The plural form of bean; more than one bean.
A bear is a big animal with a short tail. They either eat only meat or meat and plants. There are many different types of bears, for example brown bears and polar bears.
The plural form of bear; more than one bear.

If you beat someone or something, you hit it, usually many times.

Synonyms: hit, assault and batter
The past participle of beat.
If something is beautiful, it is very good to look at it.
Beauty is the quality of being nice to look at.
You use because to show the reason for something
A piece of furniture to sleep on.
The plural form of bed; more than one bed.
The bedtime is the time when someone goes to bed.
Beef is the meat of a cow.
The past participle of be.
The plural form of bee; more than one bee.

beets
plural of beet
When you begin something, you start to do the first part of a longer action.
The third-person singular form of beg.
How you behave is what you do or how you act.

When something belches, it releases in large amounts 

Synonym: burp
A belief is an idea that is thought to be true.
When you believe, you have faith in something.
The third-person singular form of believe.
The present participle of believe.
A bell is an object that is shaped like a cup that makes a ringing sound when hit.
The plural form of bell; more than one bell.
A belt is a piece of clothing worn around a person's waist. They can be used to hold up trousers or skirts, or for carrying things in pockets, such as on a utility belt.
A long seat.
The plural form of bench; more than one bench.
To change the shape of an object so that it is not straight.
With one part going in one direction and another part going in another direction.

berm (plural berms)
A narrow ledge or shelf, as along the top or bottom of a slope
A raised bank or path, especially the bank of a canal opposite the towpath
A terrace formed by wave action along a beach
A mound or bank of earth, used especially as a barrier or to provide insulation
A ledge between the parapet and the moat in a fortification
(regional, Pennsylvania) A strip of land between a street and sidewalk
A small, round fruit that grows on some plants and trees.
The superlative form of good; most good.
When you bet, you take a chance with money or something else on the result of a future event.

bib (plural bibs)
An item of clothing for babies tied around their neck to protect their clothes from getting dirty when eating.
Similar items of clothing such as the Chinese dudou and Vietnamese yem.
(sports) A rectangular piece of material, carrying a bib number, worn as identification by entrants in a race
(sports) A colourful polyester or plastic vest worn over one's clothes, usually to mark one's team during group activities.
The upper part of an apron or overalls.
A patch of colour around an animal's upper breast and throat.1950, Arthur Cleveland Bent, Life Histories of North American Wagtails, Shrikes, Vireos, and their AlliesIn summer the whole throat and breast are black, but in winter plumage the throat is white bounded by a horseshoe-shaped black bib.2011, Arthur Peacock, Gettysburg the Cat (page 22)He don't look anything like the captain. This here cat has got a nice thick black coat of fur with a nice white bib and white feet.
1950, Arthur Cleveland Bent, Life Histories of North American Wagtails, Shrikes, Vireos, and their AlliesIn summer the whole throat and breast are black, but in winter plumage the throat is white bounded by a horseshoe-shaped black bib.
2011, Arthur Peacock, Gettysburg the Cat (page 22)He don't look anything like the captain. This here cat has got a nice thick black coat of fur with a nice white bib and white feet.
A north Atlantic fish (Trisopterus luscus), allied to the cod; the pouting.
A bibcock.

bibs
plural of bib
A bid is an offer to enter into a contract to buy something or to do some kind of job.

If something is big, it is large in size; tall, wide, long, or fat.

Synonyms: good, great, high and large


Antonyms: little and small
A short form of bicycle.

bilk (plural bilks)
(cribbage) The spoiling of someone's score in the crib.
(obsolete) A deception, a hoax.

billionth (not comparable)
The ordinal form of the number one billion.

A bin is a container for garbage.

Synonyms: garbage can, trash can and waste paper basket
If you bind something put rope or string around it, often many times.

binge (plural binges)
A short period of excessive consumption, especially of excessive alcohol consumption.
(eating disorder) A rapid and excessive consumption of food.
Biology is a type of science that studies living things like plants and animals.

A bird is a warm-blooded animal that has feathers and wings and lays eggs. Most birds can fly.

Synonym: birdy
The day you were born.
A biscuit is a cookie.
A bit is an amount, usually a small amount.
If a person or animal bites something, they put it between their teeth and squeeze.
The plural form of bite; more than one bite.
The plural form of bit; more than one bit.

blab (third-person singular simple present blabs, present participle blabbing, simple past and past participle blabbed)
(transitive, intransitive) To tell tales; to gossip without reserve or discretion.TennysonAnd yonder a vile physician blabbing / The case of his patient.
TennysonAnd yonder a vile physician blabbing / The case of his patient.
The darkest color; with no light; the color of the sky at night.
A blade is something with a long, sharp edge. Things like knives, swords and razors have blades.
The plural form of blade; more than one blade.
If you blame someone or something for something bad, you say or think that they are the reason for or cause of it.

blanch (third-person singular simple present blanches, present participle blanching, simple past and past participle blanched)
(intransitive) To grow or become whiteHis cheek blanched with fear.The rose blanches in the sun.
(transitive) To take the color out of, and make white; to bleachto blanch linenAge has blanched his hair.
(transitive, cooking) To cook by dipping briefly into boiling water, then directly into cold water.
(transitive) To whiten, for example the surface of meat, by plunging into boiling water and afterwards into cold, so as to harden the surface and retain the juices
(transitive) To bleach by excluding the light, for example the stalks or leaves of plants, by earthing them up or tying them together
(transitive) To make white by removing the skin of, for example by scaldingto blanch almonds
(transitive) To give a white lustre to (silver, before stamping, in the process of coining)
(tntransitive) To cover (sheet iron) with a coating of tin.
(transitive, figuratively) To give a favorable appearance to; to whitewash; to whiten;Synonyms: palliate17th century, John Tillotson, The indispensable necessity of the knowledge of the Holy ScriptureBlanch over the blackest and most absurd things.
17th century, John Tillotson, The indispensable necessity of the knowledge of the Holy ScriptureBlanch over the blackest and most absurd things.

bland (third-person singular simple present blands, present participle blanding, simple past and past participle blanded)
(transitive, Britain  dialectal) To mix; blend; mingle.
(transitive, Britain  dialectal) To connect; associate.
If a piece of paper or something else is blank, it has nothing written on it.

blarney (uncountable)
Mindless chatter.He is full of blarney.
Ability to talk constantly.
Persuasive flattery or kind speech; smooth, wheedling talk; flattery.
A blast is when something blows up or explodes.
A blaze is a fire that makes a lot of flames and light.
Bleaching something means to make it become white or even colorless.

bleak (comparative bleaker, superlative bleakest)
Without color; pale; pallid.FoxeWhen she came out she looked as pale and as bleak as one that were laid out dead.
FoxeWhen she came out she looked as pale and as bleak as one that were laid out dead.
Desolate and exposed; swept by cold winds.WordsworthWastes too bleak to rear / The common growth of earth, the foodful ear.Longfellowat daybreak, on the bleak sea beachA bleak and bare rock.They escaped across the bleak landscape.A bleak, crater-pocked moonscape.We hiked across open meadows and climbed bleak mountains.
WordsworthWastes too bleak to rear / The common growth of earth, the foodful ear.
Longfellowat daybreak, on the bleak sea beach
Unhappy; cheerless; miserable; emotionally desolate.Downtown Albany felt bleak that February after the divorce.A bleak future is in store for you.The news is bleak.The survey paints a bleak picture.

A bleat is the sound a sheep or a goat makes.

Synonyms: baa, baaing and bleating
If you bleed, you lose blood from your body.

blend (plural blends)
A mixture of two or more things.Their music has been described as a blend of jazz and heavy metal.Our department has a good blend of experienced workers and young promise.
(linguistics) A word formed by combining two other words; a grammatical contamination, portmanteau word.The word brunch is a blend of the words breakfast and lunch.
You say, bless you when someone sneezes.
The third-person singular form of bless.
The past tense of blow.

blight (countable and uncountable, plural blights)
(phytopathology) any of many plant diseases causing damage to, or the death of, leaves, fruit or other parts
the bacterium, virus or fungus that causes such a condition
(by extension) anything that impedes growth or development or spoils any other aspect of life
A blimp is a small airship used for observation.
If someone or something is blind, then it cannot see.
If you blink, you close your eyes for a very short time.

bliss (countable and uncountable, plural blisses)
perfect happiness
A vague shape or amount; something without definite shape, especially a liquid or semi-solid substance.
A block is a hard piece of material, usually with six smooth sides.
The plural form of block; more than one block.
;  A blond is a person with good looking skin and hair.
Blood is a red liquid inside a person or animal's body that carries nutrients and oxygen to the other parts of the body.
A stain, spot or mark left by a colored object.
If wind, air, etc. blows, it moves.
The past participle of blow.
The third-person singular form of blow.
One of the colors people can see:
A bluff is an action which suggests you are strong when you are not.
When something is blunt, it has a thick end and is not sharp.

blurb (plural blurbs)
A short description of a book, film, or other work, written and used for promotional purposes.
If you blurt something out, then you are speaking quickly without thinking.
The past tense and past participle of blurt.

boa (plural boas or boae)
Any of a group of large American snakes, of the genus Boa, including the boa constrictor, the emperor boa of Mexico, and the chevalier boa of Peru.
(plural "boas") A type of scarf typically made from feathers.
To boast means to brag about yourself. Usually about what you do, and the good things about you.
A boat is a vehicle used to travel on water.
If someone is bold, that means they are brave and willing to take risks.

If you collect some things, you bring them together as a group.

collectively (not comparable)
in a collective manner; viewed together as a whole; to be treated as a single unit, rather than the items that make up the collection separately.
A collector is somebody who collects things, usually things that are rare and interesting.
The third-person singular form of collect.
A college is a school for adults who have finished high school.
The plural form of color; more than one color.

colt (plural colts)

A youthful or inexperienced person; a novice.1594, William Shakespeare, The Merchant of Venice, I. ii. 38:Ay, that's a colt indeed, for he doth nothing but / talk of his horse, and he makes it a great appropriation to / his own good parts that he can shoe him himself.

colts
plural of colt
A columnist is someone who writes for a newspaper or magazine who offers opinions and a point of view.

coma (plural comas)
A state of unconsciousness from which one may not wake up, usually induced by some form of trauma.
A person moves a comb through their hair many times to make their hair look nice.
To move towards a place or into a place; to move to the place where the person who is talking is.
The third-person singular form of come.
A comic is a person whose job is telling jokes or trying to be funny.
The plural form of comic; more than one comic.
The present participle of come.
A comment is a short statement about something; usually it is an opinion.

The plural form of comment; more than one comment.
A commitment is a formal promise or agreement.
A group of people that come together to do something or decide something.
A communist is a person who supports the political idea of communism, which believes in everyone owning everything .
A commute is a regular journey to work or to school.

A companion is somebody who you spend time with, usually because you enjoy being with them.

companionship (countable and uncountable, plural companionships)
The state of having or being a companion.
(archaic) An association, a fellowship.a companionship of printers
The state of being a journeyman.
An organized group of people.
If you compare two things, you look at, talk about, or think about how they are the same and how they are different.

compartment (plural compartments)
A room, or section, or chamberTwo men were seated in a well-lighted compartment of a third-class railway carriage.
One of the parts into which an area is subdivided.
(biochemistry) Part of a protein that serves a specific function.
(heraldry) A mound (often of grass) beneath the shield in a coat of arms on which the supporters stand.
(anatomy) A region in the body, delimited by a biological membrane.
If you compensate somebody, you give them something because they have lost something or done something for you.
If something is complex, it has lots of parts or pieces, or is difficult to understand.
A compliment is a few words of praise: saying that someone or something is good in some way.

comply (third-person singular simple present complies, present participle complying, simple past and past participle complied)
To yield assent; to accord; agree, or acquiesce; to adapt oneself; to consent or conform.John Milton (1608-1674)Yet this be sure, in nothing to comply, / Scandalous or forbidden in our law.John Tillotson (1630-1694)They did servilely comply with the people in worshiping God by sensible images.1664?, Samuel Butler, HudibrasHe that complies against his will / Is of his own opinion still.1922,  Ben Travers,  chapter 6, in  A Cuckoo in the Nest:But Sophia's mother was not the woman to brook defiance. If you conduct an activity or process, you do it or carry it out.
A conflict is when two or more people or ideas don't agree.
If you are confronted with something, you come face to face with it.
If you confuse someone, they don't understand what you have said or done.

connective (not comparable)

If something is consistent, it is regular and you can guess what it will be like in the future.

consistently (comparative more consistently, superlative most consistently)

constructively (comparative more constructively, superlative most constructively)

,  The contents of a container, such as a bag, a file, a book etc., are the things that are in it.

contestant (plural contestants)

If something continues, it does not stop.

contractor (plural contractors)

I'm glad I'm a highly-paid contractor. I'll be increasing my skills while you fight to get oxygen to your brains.

Negative statements

Emphasis

gristle (countable and uncountable, plural gristles)
Cartilage; now especially: cartilage present, as a tough substance, in meat.1979, Monty Python, Always Look on the Bright Side of LifeWhen you're chewing on life's gristleDon't grumble, give a whistleAnd this'll help things turn out for the best...
1979, Monty Python, Always Look on the Bright Side of LifeWhen you're chewing on life's gristleDon't grumble, give a whistleAnd this'll help things turn out for the best...
(figuratively, from obsolete scientific theory) Bone not yet hardened by age and hard work.1849, Herman Melville, Redburn. His First Voyage,And it is a hard and cruel thing thus in early youth to taste beforehand the pangs which should be reserved for the stout time of manhood, when the gristle has become bone, and we stand up and fight out our lives, as a thing tried before and foreseen; for then we are veterans used to sieges and battles, and not green recruits, recoiling at the first shock of the encounter.1859, George Eliot, Adam Bede,Look at Adam through the rest of the day, as he stands on the scaffolding with the two-feet ruler in his hand, whistling low while he considers how a difficulty about a floor-joist or a window-frame is to be overcome; or as he pushes one of the younger workmen aside and takes his place in upheaving a weight of timber, saying, "Let alone, lad! Thee'st got too much gristle i' thy bones yet"; or as he fixes his keen black eyes on the motions of a workman on the other side of the room and warns him that his distances are not right.1885, Ada Sarah Ballin, The Science of Dress in Theory and Practice,It. must be borne in mind that the bones of a young infant are little more than gristle, and are liable to bend, and so become deformed.1896, Arthur Conan Doyle, Rodney Stone,"The young 'un will make his way," said Belcher, who had come across to us. "He's more a sparrer than a fighter just at present, but when his gristle sets he'll take on anything on the list.

Ahyong, Marine Decapod Crustacea of Southern Australia: A Guide to Identification, page 145,Most shrimps belong to one of several families of the Infraorder Caridea (Chapter 4). However, coral shrimps and Venus shrimps are so different from the rest that a separate infraorder is warranted.
(uncountable) The flesh of such crustaceans.
(slang) A small, puny or unimportant person.
The plural form of shrub; more than one shrub.

When someone moves a door so that people can't go through it, the person is shutting the door. When someone puts their lips together so that no air or food can go in or out of their mouth, the person is shutting their mouth.

When you are shy, you are easily frightened, afraid, or careful.

sickish (comparative more sickish, superlative most sickish)

sideswipe (plural sideswipes)

sifted (not comparable)

silo (plural silos)
(agriculture) A vertical building, usually cylindrical, used for the storage of grain.
(military) An underground bunker used to hold missiles which may be launched.
(pejorative, management) An organizational unit that has poor interaction with other units, negatively affecting overall performance.2006, Albert J. Mills, Jean C. Helms Mills, John Bratton, Organizational Behaviour in a Global Context, Page 116A silo is created when members in one department or function do not interact with those in another department, even though there might be operational benefits to the interaction.
2006, Albert J. Mills, Jean C. Helms Mills, John Bratton, Organizational Behaviour in a Global Context, Page 116A silo is created when members in one department or function do not interact with those in another department, even though there might be operational benefits to the interaction.
(pejorative, informatics) A structure in the information system that is poorly networked with other structures, with data exchange hampered.Our networking is organized in silos, and employees lose time manually transferring data.
(pejorative, slang) A self-enclosed group of like-minded individuals.

silt (countable and uncountable, plural silts)

skid (plural skids)
An out-of-control sliding motion as would result from applying the brakes too hard in a car.Just before hitting the guardrail the driver was able to regain control and pull out of the skid.
A shoe or clog, as of iron, attached to a chain, and placed under the wheel of a wagon to prevent its turning when descending a steep hill; a drag; a skidpan.
(by extension) A hook attached to a chain, used for the same purpose.
A piece of timber or other material used as a support, or to receive pressure.A runner of a sled.In the hours before daylight he sharpened the skids and tightened the lashings to prepare for the long dogsled journey.A ski-shaped runner or supporting surface as found on a helicopter or other aircraft in place of wheels.Due to frequent arctic travel, the plane was equipped with long skids for snow and ice landings.A basic platform for the storage and transport of goods, machinery or equipment, later developed into the pallet.He unloaded six skids of boxes from the truck.(nautical, in the plural) Large fenders hung over a vessel's side to protect it when handling cargo.(Can we find and add a quotation of Totten to this entry?)One of a pair of horizontal rails or timbers for supporting anything, such as a boat or barrel.

A ski-shaped runner or supporting surface as found on a helicopter or other aircraft in place of wheels.Due to frequent arctic travel, the plane was equipped with long skids for snow and ice landings.
A basic platform for the storage and transport of goods, machinery or equipment, later developed into the pallet.He unloaded six skids of boxes from the truck.

One of a pair of horizontal rails or timbers for supporting anything, such as a boat or barrel.

(transitive) To pass near the surface of; to brush the surface of; to glide swiftly along the surface of.HazlittHomer describes Mercury as flinging himself from the top of Olympus, and skimming the surface of the ocean.

(transitive) to scrape off; to remove (something) from a surface

A term is a word or group of words, usually one with a special meaning in a particular field or area.
If something is terrible, it's very bad.
A person's, animal's, or group's territory is land he, she, or they claim, own, or control.
Very strong or intense fear.
A test is writing that many learners do in a room at the same time so that people are able to see how much knowledge the learners have.
Used to compare two things that are not equal.
To say a good word after someone gives something to you or after someone does something good for you.
If you are thankful for or about something, you want to say "thank you" because of it.
You say thanks when somebody has helped you or done something nice for you.
Used to show which thing we are talking about; used with things that are not close to the speaker.
The present participle of thaw.
Used, instead of a, to reference something specific, already known to exist.
A theft is when someone steals something.
If something belongs to them it is their thing.
If something is theirs, it belongs to them.
Other people; not you or the people you are talking to.
A theme is a general idea that runs through a conversation, story, group of images, piece of music, etc.
At that time; not now.
You use there to say that something exists.
The plural form of this; more than one this.
"They" is used to talk about two or more people, not you or the person you are speaking to.
If something is thick, there is some distance from one side to the other.
A thief is a person who steals.
The thigh is the part of the human leg between the hip and the knee.

thimble (plural thimbles)

A similarly shaped socket in machinery.
A thimbleful.
(nautical) A ring of metal or rope used in a ship's rigging; it is a protection against chafing.
If something is thin, there is a short distance from one side to the other.
The plural form of thing; more than one thing.
If you think something, you feel that it is or may be true.
The third-person singular form of think.

When somebody is thirsty, they feel like they need to have a drink.

thirtieth (not comparable)

The number 30.

thirty-one
The cardinal number immediately following thirty and before thirty-two; thirty plus one.
You use this to show which thing or idea you are talking about. You use it when the thing or idea is close to you.
A thorn is a sharp thing on part of a plant.
The plural form of that; more than one that.
When you have a thought, you have an idea or concept in the mind.
The number 1,000.

thousandth (not comparable)
The ordinal form of the number one thousand.
A thread is a long, very thin, soft material used to join or make cloth.
The number 3.
A thrill is an intense excitement.
Your throat is a tube inside your neck. It takes air from your mouth to your lungs.
A ceremonial chair for a sovereign, bishop or leader.

throttle (plural throttles)
A valve that regulates the supply of fuel-air mixture to an internal combustion engine and thus controls its speed; a similar valve that controls the air supply to an engine.

The windpipe or trachea.(Can we find and add a quotation of Sir Walter Scott to this entry?)
To go through is to go into one side of something and come out the other side.
The third-person singular form of throw.

thud (plural thuds)

In gardening, an over-vigorous plant that spreads and dominates the flowerbed.

Something that is tiny is very small.
The tip of something is the farthest point of it.

Near; close; in the same place; not far; in a family or group.

A drink that supposedly can make you stronger.
